articles.title: Climate costs to skyrocket for local government, analysis finds
articles.author: Tom Ravlic
articles.summary: Local governments across Australia are facing increasing costs related to climate change. Costs for insurance for local councils are 21 times higher than they were 20 years ago, while revenue from sources such as council rates is only three times higher. There are also lower payouts from insurers for the impacts of certain types of disasters, which make it difficult for individuals, businesses and local governments to recover.

articles.title: High chance of fall La Niña forming: Here's how it could affect weather in the Bay Area
articles.author: John Ross Ferrara
articles.summary: Chances of a La Niña forming in the Pacific Ocean during October, November and December has increased from 56% to 71%. This shift presents a better chance of winter precipitation for the Bay Area. However, this prediction may change as winter approaches and the odds of a winter La Niñas drop to 54%.

articles.title: Decades of surveys show whale migration shift
articles.author: The Echo
articles.summary: The eastern Australian population of humpback whales has grown from 300 in the 1960s to around 40,000. The return migration from northern breeding grounds has shifted earlier by approximately three weeks since 2021. Less sea ice means less algae which is crucial food for krill.

articles.title: 300-day climate action plan on cards
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Malik's ministry is preparing a 300-day implementation plan to confront the escalating impacts of climate change. PM Sharif declared both a national climate emergency and an agricultural emergency. More than 2.5 million people have been evacuated to safer areas in Punjab and Sindh due to floods. NDMA has delivered 9,500 tons of relief supplies to flood-affected areas of Punjab.

articles.title: Panama's vanishing ocean lifeline signals a broader climate crisis
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: Panama's ocean upwelling failed for the first time in at least 40 years. The immediate cause was a dramatic reduction in the northern trade winds. The drought affecting the Panama Canal is also linked to this climate disruption. The failure disrupts the entire marine food web, leading to reduced fish catches and increasing the risk of coral bleaching.

articles.title: Queenslanders leading the way in surprising driver trend
articles.author: Peter Fegan
articles.summary: A report has revealed that Queenslanders are leading the way in a surprising driver trend. Peter Fegan is the host of the 4BC podcast and the 4 BC App on iOS or Android.       .   - The 4BC App is free and available on iOS and Android.

articles.title: Pakistan's Floods Are a Climate Change Warning
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Pakistan has been hit by floods and extreme heat due to climate change. Critics say the government needs to do more to tackle the problem.      Â   in Pakistan is one of the most vulnerable countries to the effects of climate change, according to experts.

articles.title: 108 million degrees! Solar flares are far hotter than thought, study suggests
articles.author: Space
articles.summary: New research shows that solar flares are six times hotter than thought and calls for updated sun models that could improve space weather forecasting.    i.e. accurate sun models could improve weather forecasting in space and on the Earth.  i   in the future.

articles.title: Researchers Warn That We Can't Engineer Our Way Out of Climate Change
articles.author: Darren Orf
articles.summary: Geoengineering is seen as humanity's last line of defense against climate change, but a new study suggests that our faith might be misplaced. Scientists analyzed five geoengineering methods for protecting the polar ice caps and found that all come with immense environmental/fiscal trade-offs. Implementation timelines don't work with our need to avoid temperature increases of 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Union backs essential-service status for B.C. food inspectors after ranchers complain
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Temperatures reach 33 degrees Celsius near Kamloops, B.C., on Tuesday, June 1, 2021, as horses stand in a creek on a ranch. The Canadian flag is sponsored by HasMigrated, a company based in Waterloo, Canada.

articles.title: B.C. says deal reached with union to classify meat inspectors as essential
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Temperatures reach 33 degrees Celsius near Kamloops, B.C., on Tuesday, June 1, 2021, as horses stand in a creek on a ranch. The Canadian Press has a flag with a false flag on it. The flag is sponsored by the Peterborough Examiner.

articles.title: B.C. ranchers seek essential-service recognition as BCGEU strike disrupts inspections
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Temperatures reach 33 degrees Celsius near Kamloops, B.C., on Tuesday, June 1, 2021, as horses stand in a creek on a ranch. The Canadian flag is sponsored by HasMigrated, a company that has moved to Canada.

articles.title: Growing group of Labor MPs urge 2035 emissions target above Climate Authority's floor
articles.author: system
articles.summary: A growing cross-factional group within Labor is privately urging for Australia's next major climate target to respect the advice of the Climate Change Authority. The CCA will hand its opinion on a 2035 target to government any day and it's expected to be more conservative than the current one.

articles.title: Live Q&A: Answering your questions on wildfires and air quality
articles.summary: 2025 marks the second-worst wildfire season on record. Johanna Wagstaffe and Laura Lynch will answer your questions live about wildfires, air quality and climate change on CBC's What On Earth at 10:30 p.m. ET.

articles.title: Over 2.4m evacuated as flood threats persist in Punjab amid easing rains
articles.summary: Lt-Gen Inam Malik says 5,000 Punjab villages still underwater while rehab to begin in weeks. He says the authority delivered 9,500 tons of relief goods, including 30,000 tents, evacuated 150,000 in Sindh. PM orders 300-day climate resilience plan within next 15 days from his ministry.

articles.title: Labor MPs Call for Stricter 2035 Emissions Target Beyond Recommendations of Climate Authority
articles.author: Labour Mps Call
articles.summary: Labor MPs are calling for a more ambitious 2035 emissions reduction target than that proposed by the Climate Change Authority. The current CCA recommendation suggests a 63-75% reduction below 2005 levels by 2035. This push for stronger targets is fueled by increasing concerns about global warming, extreme weather events, and the economic opportunities presented by a green energy transition.

articles.title: Expert calls for stronger planning, tech use to tackle climate change
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: Maryam Shabbir Abbasi is an environmental expert. She has emphasized the need for stronger planning and technological advancement to reduce the impacts of climate change. If work on this project is carried out more swiftly and effectively, its outcomes can be even more significant.

articles.title: Barnstable Land Trust Brings Back Climate Conversations For Year 2
articles.author: Montana Samuels
articles.summary: This September, Barnstable Land Trust will explore climate-related topics through walks and talks during its second annual Climate Conversations series. The month-long highlights include a film screening and discussion on climate changes on Morris Island (Chatham) and a presentation on the relocation of the Sandy Neck Beach parking lot.

articles.title: Daria Tuboltseva of MIN Seeks Trade Insights from Kaprizov on Reddit's Hockey Community For a more effective title, I focused on conveying the main points of the article clearly and succinctly. I chos
articles.author: Luis Mendoza
articles.summary: The climate of Minnesota is changing due to climate change. The current mild winter conditions may be a temporary reprieve within a broader trend of climate change, according to scientists. Minnesota residents should prepare for greater climate variability and adopt sustainable practices to reduce carbon emissions. The state has over 10,000 lakes.

articles.title: N.S. researchers working to develop berries that can bear climate change
articles.summary: Climate modelling suggests the province will see wetter and hotter conditions that will affect berry crops. Scientists are preparing now, as Frances Willick reports from the province. The province is bracing itself for the change in weather and the impact on the berry crop.

articles.title: New Island Emerges in Alaska as Ice Melts
articles.author: Luis Mendoza
articles.summary: Prow Knob in southeastern Alaska has become an island after a retreating glacier pulled away. Alsek Glacier's final separation from the knob took place between July 13 and August 6. Scientists say many glaciers in Alaska and around the world are retreating as global temperatures increase. Last year was the hottest on record for global average temperatures.

articles.title: B.C. wildfire season tops average with over 840,000 hectares burned
articles.author: John Arendt
articles.summary: As of Sept. 11, 841,488 hectares had been burned in 1,241 wildfires in British Columbia. The damage from wildfires this year is significantly lower than the 2024 and 2023 wildfire seasons, but the number of hectares burned is well above the historical average.

articles.title: 'Time to Make Polluters Pay': Study Ties Fossil Fuel Pollution Directly to Deadly Heatwaves
articles.author: Jessica Corbett
articles.summary: There are calls for fossil fuel giants to pay for the deadly impacts of their products. Emissions from 14 carbon majors drove 213 major heatwaves since 2000, making >50 deadly ones 10,000 times more likely and adding up to +2.2°C increased intensity.

articles.title: PM orders 300-day plan to tackle climate change: Musadik Malik
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: PM Shehbaz Sharif ordered to prepare a 300-day implementation plan within 15 days to address climate change and the risks posed by monsoon rains and accelerated glacial melting. More than 2.4 million people evacuated in Punjab and 150,000 in Sindh due to delayed water inflows. The death toll from rains and floods has risen to over 930 nationwide.

articles.title: NDMA chief warns of more rains next week
articles.author: Malik Ashraf
articles.summary: National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) Chairman Inam Haider Malik said on Thursday that monsoon would continue for another two to three days. Malik said that flood had destroyed crops and swept away livestock in several areas of the country, but now the situation was under control in the areas of Sutlej, Ravi and Chenab. Rescue operations were underway across the country and 2.4 million people were shifted to safer places in Punjab, 1.5 million people to Sindh. More rain was expected in central Punjab and Azad Kashmir from September 16 to 18.

articles.title: A vulnerable NC faces peak hurricane season with a weakened, politicized FEMA
articles.author: Ned Barnett
articles.summary: As climate change fuels more powerful storms, the agency that helps the state prepare and recover from disasters is in disarray. FEMA is already struggling to respond to $60 billion in damages in western North Carolina nearly a year after Hurricane Helene. A major North Carolina hurricane this season would have the state asking for billions of dollars more. President Donald Trump has politicized disaster relief. FEMA has lost one-third of its full-time staff to cuts and attrition. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem has slowed FEMA payments to a trickle.

articles.title: World Athletics Championships: Is it too hot in Tokyo?
articles.author: Tasnim Chowdhury
articles.summary: Japan is experiencing its hottest summer since records began in 1898. The extreme heat is going to coincide with the 2025 World Athletics Championships, due to take place in the Japanese capital Tokyo from 13-21 September. Temperatures are expected to exceed 30C for the duration of the championships.

articles.title: La Niña Is Expected To Form Soon. Here's What That Could Mean.
articles.author: Miriam Guthrie
articles.summary: There's a 71% chance of La Niña during October through December, according to NOAA's Climate Prediction Center. ENSO-neutral conditions continued this past month, with near- to below-average sea-surface temperatures across the central and eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean. La Niñas can affect weather patterns thousands of miles away, including near the U.S.

articles.title: Shrinking states: a positive future with fewer people?
articles.author: Madeleine Finlay
articles.summary: Fertility rate in England and Wales has fallen for the third year in a row. Two-thirds of the global population now lives in countries with low fertility rates, as is the case in England.    - Ross Burns, Ellie Bury.

articles.title: CIBSE Board Member Professor Dejan Mumovic strengthens international collaboration with lecture series in Australia
articles.author: Pressat
articles.summary: Professor Dejan Mumovic recently completed a lecture and presentation tour in Australia. He shared his expertise on climate resilience and building performance in the CIBSE on Thursday 11 September, 2025. He is a board member of the organisation and a professor at the University of Canberra.

articles.title: Reform council to ‘rescind' climate emergency declaration
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Kent council condemned by opposition parties. They say county is at the forefront of climate impacts and is not prepared to deal with climate change.      Â   in this context.  in the context of the current climate change situation in Kent.

articles.title: 2025 Is Earth's Second Warmest Year Behind 2024 Through August, Reports Say
articles.author: Jonathan Erdman
articles.summary: The first eight months of 2025 were Earth's second warmest on record, according to European Copernicus Climate Change Service. It was the warmest summer on record in the U.K., Ireland, China, Japan and South Korea. Arizona had its third hottest summer, and both Oregon and Washington had their fourth hottest summers since 1895. New Hampshire and Vermont had the driest summers on record.

articles.title: Get the Facts Straight, The Independent, Island Nations Are Growing, Not 'Sinking Into the Sea'
articles.author: Watts Up With That
articles.summary: The Independent claims small island nations are sinking into the sea due to climate change. The island nations discussed in the story are actually growing in size, not sinking beneath the seas. They have expanded infrastructure and seen long-term, large-scale investments on their islands in recent years.

articles.title: Climate Change Deepens Hunger and Thirst in the Region.
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Rising heat in Central America is bringing harsher droughts, stronger floods, deadly storms, heat waves, and failing crops. Groups under the Central America Vulnerables banner are pressing governments to act quickly. They want laws that protect soil, back artisanal fishers, improve local risk planning, and enshrine climate, food, environment, and human rights protections.

articles.title: Embracing Climate-Smart Growth is a Net Win for Uganda
articles.author: APO
articles.summary: Climate change could cut Uganda's economic growth by up to 3.1% by 2050. More than 613,000 people could be pushed into poverty and 12 million more into internal migration. Uganda is the 14th most climate-vulnerable country in the world.

articles.title: CRCL Names Lifetime Achievement Award Honoree
articles.author: Site Staff
articles.summary: Mark Schleifstein is the recipient of the Coalition to Restore Coastal Louisiana's 2025 Lifetime Achievement Award. He will be honored on November 13 at SoLou restaurant in Baton Rouge. CRCL is also presenting six Coastal Stewardship Awards. The winners are selected by a committee comprised of Louisiana residents from across the coast. Tickets for the night can be purchased online.

articles.title: Rising temperatures could be causing obesity
articles.author: Bang Showbiz
articles.summary: People are more likely to get fat during warmer weather as they gorge on ice cream and drink fizzy drinks to stay cool and hydrated. At temperatures between 12C and 30C, people consume 0.7 grams more sugar per day for each degree hotter than 12C. At 25C, they eat over 2 teaspoons per day.

articles.title: Letter: A planet reshaped by our choices
articles.summary: Robert Pelton writes to the editor that climate change is real, measurable and directly linked to human activities. The past decade was the hottest on record, extreme weather events are growing in intensity, heatwaves, heavy rainfall and wildfires are occurring more frequently and with greater severity. Greenland and Antarctica are losing mass at accelerating rates.

articles.title: Climate change responsible for 1,700 heat-related deaths in a single European region, study finds
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: There were 1,700 heat-related deaths in the canton of Zurich between 1969 and 2018 due to climate change, according to the Swiss government.       -  -   in the Swiss canton Zurich between 2009 and 2018.

articles.title: UK town's £57m mega-project to stop famous beach disappearing into the sea
articles.author: Aakifah Gani
articles.summary: The Blackpool Beach Management scheme proposes building 17 rock headlands along the central coastline from south of South Pier to Cocker Square near North Pier to protect the town's beaches from climate change. The project will cost £57 million. Construction is expected to start in spring 2026 and wrap up by spring 2029. The consultation runs until October 31.

articles.title: Study links heat waves to pollution from major fossil fuel producers
articles.author: Naharnet
articles.summary: Fifty-five heat waves over the past quarter-century would not have happened without human-caused climate change, according to a study published Wednesday. Planet-warming emissions from 180 major cement, oil and gas producers contributed to the heat waves, the study found.

articles.title: New Study Dramatically Rewrites Human History in Australia
articles.author: Declan Gallagher
articles.summary: A new study published in the journal Archaeology in Oceania has revealed shocking information about modern humans in Australia. It determined that modern humans arrived in Australia only 50,000 years ago. This is markedly different from previous studies, which had dated human arrival on the continent to roughly 65,000. The results corroborate a recent study, which determined that humans and Neanderthals interbred somewhere between 43,500 and 51,500 years ago, so the ancestors of modern Aboriginal Australians could not have arrived before this period.

The results of this study corroborate a recent study that determined that humans and Neanderthals interbred somewhere between 43,500 and 51,500 years ago, so the ancestors of modern Aboriginal Australians could not have arrived before this period.

articles.title: Ladakh's Changmolung Glacier Melting Fast, Hot Water Springs Main Reason: Wadia Institute Scientist
articles.author: Rohit Kumar
articles.summary: There are 9,575 glaciers in India, of which 5,262 are in the Ladakh region, which has the highest number of glaciers. Global warming, climate change and geothermal springs contribute to the rapid melting of glaciers in the Himalayan regions of the country.

articles.title: From United States to China, 5 largest countries in the world by area
articles.summary: Russia is the largest country by area in the world. It covers about 17,098,242 sq km, which is more than one-eighth of all land on Earth. Its land area alone is 16,376,870 sq km and covers 11 percent of the world's landmass.

articles.title: Thousands Displaced In Kenya Amid Fears of Rising Lake Naivasha
articles.summary: Thousands of families have been forced to leave their homes due to rising water levels of Lake Naivasha northwest of Nairobi. The flow of agro-chemicals and sewage into the lake is posing environmental risks, local authorities have warned. Deputy County Commissioner Josiah Odongo has called on residents not to ignore relocation orders.

articles.title: Study links heat waves to pollution from major fossil fuel producers
articles.author: Naharnet Newsdesk
articles.summary: Fifty-five heat waves over the past quarter-century would not have happened without human-caused climate change, according to a study published in the journal Nature. Global warming made all 213 of the heat waves examined more likely. Cement, oil and gas producers are responsible for 57% of all the carbon dioxide emitted from 1850 to 2023.

articles.title: Study links fossil fuel giants to surge in heatwaves
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Fossil fuel companies and cement producers play a direct role in driving the frequency and intensity of deadly heatwaves, according to research published in the journal Nature. There were 213 significant heatwaves in the last 213 years, according the study, which was based on data from 213 heatwaves.

articles.title: No see sea level acceleration
articles.author: John Robson
articles.summary: On CDN's Sea Level Check series, CDN readers went on a tour of coastal spots where sea levels are rising slowly. The alarmists say sea level rise is now accelerating due to climate change so it's not a good idea to worry about it.

articles.title: Severe drought expands across Vermont, New Hampshire, and Northern New York
articles.author: Marissa Vigevani
articles.summary: Severe drought conditions are spreading across Vermont, New Hampshire and northern New York. About 60% of Vermont is now in severe drought, up from 34% last week. In New Hampshire, southern Grafton County has entered extreme drought, the second-highest category on the U.S. Drought Monitor.

articles.title: The £57m mega-project to save popular UK seaside town's famous beach
articles.author: Jennifer Pinto
articles.summary: Blackpool Council is planning a £57 million coastal defence project to protect the town's beaches from erosion. Beach levels along Blackpool's coast have been declining. The erosion has already exposed the foundations of the central pier. 21.5 million visitors visited Blackpool in the past year.

articles.title: Introducing War on Climate, a new series that explores how conflict interacts with environmental issues ...
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: The world is the most violent it has been in decades. There were 61 conflicts across 36 countries last year, the highest level since 1946. Wars are incredibly environmentally destructive and raise questions about the need for more strategic restraint and whether the business of war can be rendered less environmentally destructive.

articles.title: Extreme heat poses threat to food supply
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: Organizations from Central America Vulnerables warn that rising temperatures in the region are intensifying droughts, floods, storms, heat waves, and crop losses. They are calling on Central American governments to take urgent action to curb climate change and halt the expansion of open-pit mining.

articles.title: La Nina's ground shifts threaten Australian homes: study
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Australia's intensifying La Nina cycles bring heavy rains that are causing ground movement. La Nina rainfall is increasing shrink-swell in clay soils, destabilizing foundations and cracking. Even small shifts in climate cycles can lead to cracking, subsidence or costly repairs.

articles.title: The Colombian coastal village reinventing itself as seas rise
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Intense high tides destroyed homes and businesses in Juanchaco and affected 3,000 families. Afro-Colombian community that live there are choosing to 'stay in a different way' because of the flooding.      Â

articles.title: Alaska climate report: August, a time of meteorological change
articles.author: Alaska Native News
articles.summary: Kotzebue, Nome and Bethel had warm weather in the first week of August. Cold Bay, Juneau, and stations in the Interior set several records for daily temperatures during a warm spell in the last third of the month. Kotzebue had a record wet month, receiving 5.36 inches of rain for 252% of normal. Southcentral and Southeast Alaska were relatively dry. Alaska Climate Research Center released its statewide August climate summary earlier this month.

articles.title: Researchers Warn That We Can't Engineer Our Way Out of Climate Change
articles.author: Darren Orf
articles.summary: 2024 will be the warmest year on record. Scientists and experts are considering more drastic measures to reverse the oncoming environmental devastation. The methods analyzed in the study include stratospheric aerosol injections, sea curtains, sea ice management, basal water removal, and ocean fertilization. Almost every part of the geoengineering plan has negative consequences.

articles.title: Study links fossil fuel giants to surge in heatwaves
articles.author: News Room
articles.summary: Fossil fuel and cement producers have played a direct role in driving the frequency and intensity of deadly heatwaves, according to a study published in the journal Nature. Global warming made heatwaves 20 times more likely between 2000 and 2009 and 200 times more so from 2010 to 2019.

articles.title: Emissions from fossil fuel, cement giants made heatwaves 50% more intense since pre-industrial era: Study
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Emissions from fossil fuel and cement producers could be directly responsible for making an average heatwave "50 per cent more intense" since the pre-industrial era. The emissions from a single carbon major could have contributed to as many as "16 to 53 heatwaves" that would have been impossible without global warming.

articles.title: Europe leads on transparent borders as Australia lags behind
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: New research shows that Australia is lagging behind Europe when it comes to economic growth.       in terms of GDP per capita, Australia lags well behind Europe's economic growth compared to other developed countries, according to the research. It also lags behind the rest of Europe.

articles.title: NiMet DG calls for stronger investment, collaboration in climate services
articles.author: Kelvin Osa Okunbor
articles.summary: NiMet DG calls for stronger investment, collaboration in climate services. Professor Charles Anosike spoke at the maiden Stakeholders' Forum in Lagos. He urged greater collaboration and investment in weather and climate services to safeguard lives and strengthen socio-economic resilience amid rising climate risks.

articles.title: New Research Finds ‘No Statistically Significant Acceleration' In Global Sea Level Rise
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: As of 2020, 95% of the tide gauges reliably contribute to estimates of global sea level rise show there has been no statistical acceleration in the modern rate of rise. The 5% of gauges that do indicate acceleration cannot be attributed to 'global warming' or climate change, but to local or geologic factors such as vertical land motions. In 2020, the global rise rate is only 1.5 mm/year. IPCC models project sea levels should be rising at a rate of about 3.5mm per year.

articles.title: La Niña's New Twist: Ground Movement Threatens Aussie Homes
articles.author: Phys.org
articles.summary: La Niña's increasingly intense weather cycles pose new challenges for owners, constructors and infrastructure planners. The University of South Australia's research was published in the Journal of Environmental Management (JEM). UNISA's research is based on research from the UNISA.

articles.title: Africa: Experts Launch a Climate and Health Curriculum for African Negotiators At COP30
articles.author: Farai Shawn Matiashe
articles.summary: Amref Health Africa launched a Climate Change and Health Negotiators' curriculum on 9 September at the Second Africa Climate Summit in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Health is underrepresented in climate negotiations. Africa contributes less than 4 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions, but it continues to experience the effects of climate change. The cost of climate adaptation in sub-Saharan Africa would be between USD 30 and USD 50 billion annually.

articles.title: The Colombian coastal village reinventing itself as seas rise
articles.summary: The Pacific coast around Juanchaco, in the Valle del Cauca department, is experiencing accelerated erosion. More than 3,000 families have been affected since the second half of 2024. In August 2024, the governor's office declared a state of public calamity and is monitoring the damage to the coastline. Community tourism has been developing for decades around the Uramba Bahía Málaga national natural park.

articles.title: Carbon Majors Amplify Heat: How Fossil Fuel Giants Intensified Heatwaves
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Emissions from fossil fuel and cement producers have intensified heatwaves by an average of 50 percent since the pre-industrial era. Major carbon emitters like Saudi Aramco, Gazprom, and several coal-dependent countries were found to notably increase the likelihood of these extreme weather events.

articles.title: Chenab, Sutlej rivers hit extremely high flood levels
articles.author: Maleeha Zahid
articles.summary: The River Chenab at Head Panjnad in Punjab is facing an extremely high-level flood situation, with water levels rising again after a brief decline over the past three days. The flood waters pose a serious risk to communities, farmland, and infrastructure along the riverbanks. The floods have caused severe damage to Punjab's agricultural economy, affecting 2.125 million acres of farmland.

articles.title: Flood alerts in place for St Dogmaels, Cardigan and Amroth along coast
articles.author: Chloe Atkinson
articles.summary: Natural Resources Wales has issued a flood alert for the Pembrokeshire Coast between St Dogmaels, Cardigan and Amroth. The alert was first issued yesterday (September 8) around 20:00pm and has now been in place for 4 days.

articles.title: Human behaviour, rats trigger Lassa feverEpidemiologist
articles.author: Punch
articles.summary: Ondo State Epidemiologist, Dr Stephen Fagbemi, has said human behaviour and weather changes are some of the reasons why Lassa fever is rampant during dry seasons. The activities of rats, and the habit of bushing burning during the dry season was also responsible for the disease.

articles.title: 25% of recent heat waves 'virtually impossible' without human-caused climate change, study finds
articles.author: Rédaction Africanews
articles.summary: Human activity responsible for climate change has led to more than 50 heat waves since the year 2000, according to a new study published in the journal Nature. Cement, oil and gas producers are responsible for 57% of all the carbon dioxide emitted from 1850 to 2023.

articles.title: Study: 25% of recent heatwaves 'virtually impossible' without man-made climate change
articles.author: Rédaction Africanews
articles.summary: Human activity responsible for climate change has led to more than 50 heat waves since the year 2000, according to a new study published in the journal Nature. Cement, oil and gas producers are responsible for 57% of all the carbon dioxide emitted from 1850 to 2023.

articles.title: ‘Living in fear since 1999': Locals share concerns as Jagatsinghpur coast continues to erode
articles.author: Srijata Mishra
articles.summary: The sea has breached the coastline near Siali and Ramtara in Jagatsinghpur district. The continuous ingress of seawater over the past four days has left residents anxious and farmlands devastated. Villagers have renewed calls for concrete coastal protection measures, including mangrove plantation and construction of a sea wall to safeguard lives and livelihoods.

articles.title: Hummingbird migration 2025: What to know about maintaining feeders in Middle Tennessee
articles.author: The Tennessean
articles.summary: Hummingbirds are beginning to make their winter migration to Mexico and Central America. The Ruby-throated hummingbird flies nonstop across the Gulf of Mexico, a distance of nearly 500 miles and takes 18 to 20 hours under favorable conditions, to winter in southern Mexico or northern Central America, which is a long way away.

articles.title: EarthTalk: Helping teens understand global warming
articles.summary: New Jersey was the first state to require climate education in schools, incorporating it in 2020 in the New Jersey Student Learning Standards. In the rest of the U.S., climate education is not a primary focus in science curriculum. Teenagers can become educated on climate issues through entertainment and hands-on activities.

articles.title: Introducing War on Climate, a new series that explores how conflict interacts with environmental issues around the globe
articles.author: Sam Phelps
articles.summary: The world is the most violent it has been in decades. Last year there were 61 conflicts across 36 countries, the highest level since 1946. War degrades the environment and can fragment international cooperation on climate change. Some conflicts in the Middle East and Sahel have already been labelled 'climate wars'.

articles.title: Weatherman forecasts below-average rains in parts of Tanzania
articles.summary: The Tanzania Meteorological Authority (TMA) has projected that several parts of the country will experience normal to below-normal rainfall during the upcoming vuli season. The season runs from October to December 2025. The regions affected include Mara, Mwanza, Simiyu, Shinyanga, Arusha, Tanga and the northern coastal strip. The rains are expected to start in the first and second week of October in Kagera, Geita, Mwanaza, Mara and northern part of Kigoma. They are anticipated to commence in early to mid-November over the northeastern highlands and northern coast, with the season ending in January 2026.

articles.title: ACWA Power urges climate focus in Caspian region project planning
articles.author: Alyona Pavlenko
articles.summary: Selim Güven is the Country Director of ACWA Power to Azerbaijan and Türkiye. He spoke at the 2nd International Exhibition and Conference for Water Management in Baku. He said it is necessary to take climate change into account while designing facilities in the Caspian Sea region.

articles.title: Devastating floods wreck Punjab's agricultural economy
articles.author: Maleeha Zahid
articles.summary: Floods destroyed 2,125,838 acres of agricultural land in Punjab. Rice crops on 970,929 acres of land were destroyed. Cotton crops on 110,850 acres were completely washed away. Maize crops covering 186,419 acres were destroyed, leaving thousands of farmers with no source of income. Sugarcane fields on 220,344 acres were ruined, dealing a heavy blow to Punjab's sugar industry. Vegetables cultivated on 115,260 acres were lost, reducing local market supplies. Many rural communities now face food insecurity and financial distress.

articles.title: Blame the Heat? The World's Biggest Polluters Are Driving Deadly Heatwaves
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: The Earth is warming at an unprecedented rate. Extreme heatwaves are becoming more frequent, more intense, and more deadly around the globe due to human-caused climate change. ETH Zurich studied 213 heatwave events across all seven continents from 2000 to 2023. The study found that between 2000 and 2009, climate change made heatwaves about 20 times more likely. Between 2010 and 2019, they became as much as 200 times more common. The research focused on the 180 largest fossil fuel and cement producers responsible for 60% of all carbon dioxide emissions since 1850.

articles.title: IFLScience The Big Questions: Are We In The Anthropocene?
articles.author: Dr. Russell Moul
articles.summary: In March 2024 geologists rejected the proposal that we are in a new geological era: the Anthropocene, a time dominated by human activity on the planet. The evidence of our impact on the Earth's ecology and climate continues to mount up. The rest of this article is behind a paywall.

articles.title: Marine protection delays makes ocean restoration more uncertain, warn environment groups
articles.author: The Irish Times
articles.summary: The longer Irish marine ecosystems are left exposed to degradation, the more costly and uncertain their recovery becomes. articles.title: UNDP and GEF unfurl challenge in Turkmenistan to tackle Aral Sea crisis head-on
